title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Aortic arch anomalies can give rise to vascular rings, a rare vascular anomaly with significant health implications. This activity deals with understanding the embryology of the aortic arch, the anatomy of a normal aortic arch and its anomalies, types of aortic arch anomalies that can give rise to a vascular ring, its symptomatology and how to diagnose and manage a patient with a vascular ring. It will also review the role of an interprofessional team.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Continuing Education Activity. Aortic arch anomalies can give rise to vascular rings, a rare vascular anomaly with significant health implications. This activity deals with understanding the embryology of the aortic arch, the anatomy of a normal aortic arch and its anomalies, types of aortic arch anomalies that can give rise to a vascular ring, its symptomatology and how to diagnose and manage a patient with a vascular ring. It will also review the role of an interprofessional team.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Objectives: Describe the embryology of an aortic arch ring. Outline the typical imaging findings associated with an aortic arch ring. Review the management options available for an aortic arch ring. Summarize interprofessional team strategies for improving care coordination and communication to advance the care of patients with an aortic arch ring and improve outcomes. Access free multiple choice questions on this topic.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Continuing Education Activity. Objectives: Describe the embryology of an aortic arch ring. title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Introduction
content: A vascular ring is a condition in which both the trachea and the esophagus are encircled by vascular structures or its remnants (ligamentous remnant, atretic chord like remnant).
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Introduction. A vascular ring is a condition in which both the trachea and the esophagus are encircled by vascular structures or its remnants (ligamentous remnant, atretic chord like remnant).

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Introduction -- Aortic Arch
content: The transverse aortic arch gives rise to three branches, the brachiocephalic artery, the left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery. The brachiocephalic trunk then divides into the right common carotid artery and right subclavian artery.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Introduction -- Aortic Arch. The transverse aortic arch gives rise to three branches, the brachiocephalic artery, the left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery. The brachiocephalic trunk then divides into the right common carotid artery and right subclavian artery.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Introduction -- Sidedness of the Aortic Arch
content: The side of the aortic arch is determined by the bronchus that is traversed by the aortic arch. This will lead to the left aortic arch (LAA) will be on the left of the trachea, and the right aortic arch (RAA) will be on the right of the trachea.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Introduction -- Sidedness of the Aortic Arch. The side of the aortic arch is determined by the bronchus that is traversed by the aortic arch. This will lead to the left aortic arch (LAA) will be on the left of the trachea, and the right aortic arch (RAA) will be on the right of the trachea.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Introduction -- Anomalies of Aortic Arch
content: Due to several embryological alterations, the architecture of the aortic arch can be altered, giving rise to an array of different aortic arch anomalies.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Introduction -- Anomalies of Aortic Arch. Due to several embryological alterations, the architecture of the aortic arch can be altered, giving rise to an array of different aortic arch anomalies.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Introduction -- Normal Variants
content: These include a common origin of the brachiocephalic artery and the left common carotid artery, and origin of the vertebral artery between the left common carotid artery and left subclavian artery.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Introduction -- Normal Variants. These include a common origin of the brachiocephalic artery and the left common carotid artery, and origin of the vertebral artery between the left common carotid artery and left subclavian artery.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Etiology -- Embryology of Aortic Arch
content: The distal part of the truncus arteriosus is from the aortic sac. The aortic sac forms the right and left horns of the aorta, which form the aortic arches before terminating in the right and left dorsal aorta. Each pharyngeal arch receives its own artery, which is derived from the aortic arches.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Etiology -- Embryology of Aortic Arch. The distal part of the truncus arteriosus is from the aortic sac. The aortic sac forms the right and left horns of the aorta, which form the aortic arches before terminating in the right and left dorsal aorta. Each pharyngeal arch receives its own artery, which is derived from the aortic arches.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Etiology -- Aortic Arches
content: The pharyngeal arches and its vessels (aortic arches) develop during the 4th to 5th week of gestation but are not present simultaneously. They develop from cranial to caudal fashion. Initially, there are 6 aortic arches connecting the ventral aorta and the dorsal aorta. The fifth aortic arch either never forms or forms incompletely and regresses. The first arch mostly disappears, leaving behind a small portion that forms the maxillary artery. The second arch mostly disappears as well and forms the hyoid and stapedial arteries. The third, fourth, and sixth arches remain large to give rise to the vessels of the aortic arch as well as the aorta.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Etiology -- Aortic Arches. The pharyngeal arches and its vessels (aortic arches) develop during the 4th to 5th week of gestation but are not present simultaneously. They develop from cranial to caudal fashion. Initially, there are 6 aortic arches connecting the ventral aorta and the dorsal aorta. The fifth aortic arch either never forms or forms incompletely and regresses. The first arch mostly disappears, leaving behind a small portion that forms the maxillary artery. The second arch mostly disappears as well and forms the hyoid and stapedial arteries. The third, fourth, and sixth arches remain large to give rise to the vessels of the aortic arch as well as the aorta.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Etiology -- Embryological Origin
content: Right horn - brachiocephalic artery Left horn - proximal aortic arch 3rd arch - common carotid artery, external carotid artery and the proximal portion of the internal carotid artery on both the sides Left 4th arch - arch between the left common carotid artery (LCCA) and left subclavian artery (LSCA) Right 4th arch - proximal portion of right subclavian artery (RSCA) Left sixth arch - proximal portion forms the left pulmonary artery (LPA). The distal portion forms the patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Right sixth arch - proximal portion forms the right pulmonary artery (RPA). The distal portion disappears. Right dorsal aorta - right distal subclavian artery Left dorsal aorta - left aortic arch distal to LSCA
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Etiology -- Embryological Origin. Right horn - brachiocephalic artery Left horn - proximal aortic arch 3rd arch - common carotid artery, external carotid artery and the proximal portion of the internal carotid artery on both the sides Left 4th arch - arch between the left common carotid artery (LCCA) and left subclavian artery (LSCA) Right 4th arch - proximal portion of right subclavian artery (RSCA) Left sixth arch - proximal portion forms the left pulmonary artery (LPA). The distal portion forms the patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Right sixth arch - proximal portion forms the right pulmonary artery (RPA). The distal portion disappears. Right dorsal aorta - right distal subclavian artery Left dorsal aorta - left aortic arch distal to LSCA

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Etiology -- Embryological Origin
content: Dorsal aorta - The cranial portion also forms the distal portion of internal carotid arteries on both sides. The portion of dorsal aorta between 3rd and 4th arches disappears. The portion of the right dorsal aorta between the origin of the 7th intersegmental artery and the junction with left dorsal aorta disappears as well. Right seventh intersegmental artery - distal RSCA Left seventh intersegmental artery - LSCA The above embryological knowledge is essential in understanding the formation of vascular rings that can arise from various aortic arch anomalies.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Etiology -- Embryological Origin. Dorsal aorta - The cranial portion also forms the distal portion of internal carotid arteries on both sides. The portion of dorsal aorta between 3rd and 4th arches disappears. The portion of the right dorsal aorta between the origin of the 7th intersegmental artery and the junction with left dorsal aorta disappears as well. Right seventh intersegmental artery - distal RSCA Left seventh intersegmental artery - LSCA The above embryological knowledge is essential in understanding the formation of vascular rings that can arise from various aortic arch anomalies.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Epidemiology
content: Incidence of aortic arch anomalies: Approximately 1 to 3 percent of all congenital heart disease. [1] Compared to females, males appear to have a 1.4 to 2 times greater risk of having a vascular ring than females. [2] [3] [4] Among the aortic arch anomalies that can lead to a vascular ring, the following with the first two listed below comprising more than 90% of all vascular rings seen: Double aortic arch (DAA) RAA and aberrant LSCA and left PDA Circumflex aortic arch - Either a left-sided aortic arch with a right descending aorta and right-sided PDA (or) a right-sided aortic arch with a left descending aorta and left-sided PDA Pulmonary artery sling (It is not a vascular ring in a true sense and hence called vascular sling because it passes anterior to the esophagus behind the trachea) Left-sided aortic arch (LAA) with aberrant RSCA (ONLY if right-sided PDA is present) Right-sided aortic arch (RAA) with mirror image branching (ONLY if left-sided PDA arises from descending aorta)
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Epidemiology. Incidence of aortic arch anomalies: Approximately 1 to 3 percent of all congenital heart disease. [1] Compared to females, males appear to have a 1.4 to 2 times greater risk of having a vascular ring than females. [2] [3] [4] Among the aortic arch anomalies that can lead to a vascular ring, the following with the first two listed below comprising more than 90% of all vascular rings seen: Double aortic arch (DAA) RAA and aberrant LSCA and left PDA Circumflex aortic arch - Either a left-sided aortic arch with a right descending aorta and right-sided PDA (or) a right-sided aortic arch with a left descending aorta and left-sided PDA Pulmonary artery sling (It is not a vascular ring in a true sense and hence called vascular sling because it passes anterior to the esophagus behind the trachea) Left-sided aortic arch (LAA) with aberrant RSCA (ONLY if right-sided PDA is present) Right-sided aortic arch (RAA) with mirror image branching (ONLY if left-sided PDA arises from descending aorta)

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- History and Physical
content: A high index of suspicion is needed to get to a prompt diagnosis of an aortic arch anomaly. A clue to the diagnosis is an infant or a child presenting with a history of multiple visits to the pulmonologist or a gastroenterologist with no definitive diagnosis for the underlying long-standing symptoms.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- History and Physical. A high index of suspicion is needed to get to a prompt diagnosis of an aortic arch anomaly. A clue to the diagnosis is an infant or a child presenting with a history of multiple visits to the pulmonologist or a gastroenterologist with no definitive diagnosis for the underlying long-standing symptoms.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- History and Physical -- History
content: Respiratory Symptoms [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6]
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- History and Physical -- History. Respiratory Symptoms [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6]

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- History and Physical -- History
content: Wheezing, stridor, pneumonia, upper respiratory tract infection, and respiratory distress are observed. Cough and respiratory cyanosis can also be seen. Respiratory arrest, choking, and bronchiolitis are rare. Apnea, tracheomalacia, and aspiration are extremely rare.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- History and Physical -- History. Wheezing, stridor, pneumonia, upper respiratory tract infection, and respiratory distress are observed. Cough and respiratory cyanosis can also be seen. Respiratory arrest, choking, and bronchiolitis are rare. Apnea, tracheomalacia, and aspiration are extremely rare.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- History and Physical -- Gastrointestinal Symptoms
content: Vomiting, failure to thrive, dysphagia, and choking with feeds
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- History and Physical -- Gastrointestinal Symptoms. Vomiting, failure to thrive, dysphagia, and choking with feeds

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- History and Physical -- Cardiac Symptoms
content: Murmurs, heart failure
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- History and Physical -- Cardiac Symptoms. Murmurs, heart failure

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- History and Physical -- Physical Exam
content: Completely depend upon the severity of tracheal and esophageal compression from the vascular ring. Infants can develop tracheobronchomalacia secondary to compression that, in turn, leads to "noisy breathing," which on examination presents as inspiratory stridor and occasionally rhonchi, which worsens with agitation. As the severity of compression worsens, respiratory distress/failure signs become more apparent: nasal flaring, intercostal and subcostal retractions, tachypnea, hypoxia, and cyanosis.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- History and Physical -- Physical Exam. Completely depend upon the severity of tracheal and esophageal compression from the vascular ring. Infants can develop tracheobronchomalacia secondary to compression that, in turn, leads to "noisy breathing," which on examination presents as inspiratory stridor and occasionally rhonchi, which worsens with agitation. As the severity of compression worsens, respiratory distress/failure signs become more apparent: nasal flaring, intercostal and subcostal retractions, tachypnea, hypoxia, and cyanosis.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Evaluation -- Chest X-ray
content: Posteroanterior and lateral views are needed to rule out underlying respiratory pathologies, clues to any associated congenital heart disease. If a vascular ring is present, the anterior bowing trachea is noted on the lateral radiograph.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Evaluation -- Chest X-ray. Posteroanterior and lateral views are needed to rule out underlying respiratory pathologies, clues to any associated congenital heart disease. If a vascular ring is present, the anterior bowing trachea is noted on the lateral radiograph.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Evaluation -- Computed Tomography or Magnetic Resonance Angiography
content: These provide advanced imaging of the vascular ring in three-dimensional perspective leading to better visualization and localization Advantages of CTA: better visualization of airways. Disadvantage of CTA: radiation exposure Advantages of MRA: no radiation. Disadvantage of MRA: prolonged testing needing sedation/anesthesia
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Evaluation -- Computed Tomography or Magnetic Resonance Angiography. These provide advanced imaging of the vascular ring in three-dimensional perspective leading to better visualization and localization Advantages of CTA: better visualization of airways. Disadvantage of CTA: radiation exposure Advantages of MRA: no radiation. Disadvantage of MRA: prolonged testing needing sedation/anesthesia

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Evaluation -- Echocardiography
content: Echocardiography at the hands of an experienced technician can detect vascular anomalies. [7] More commonly, preoperative echocardiography is often performed to identify the presence of congenital heart disease.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Evaluation -- Echocardiography. Echocardiography at the hands of an experienced technician can detect vascular anomalies. [7] More commonly, preoperative echocardiography is often performed to identify the presence of congenital heart disease.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Evaluation -- Echocardiography
content: Advantage of echocardiogram: Noninvasive, readily available, no radiation exposure. Disadvantage of echocardiogram: Cannot identify atretic segments and can also be affected due to poor acoustic windows
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Evaluation -- Echocardiography. Advantage of echocardiogram: Noninvasive, readily available, no radiation exposure. Disadvantage of echocardiogram: Cannot identify atretic segments and can also be affected due to poor acoustic windows

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Evaluation -- Bronchoscopy
content: Bronchoscopy is not useful in the identification of vascular rings. It is done in certain institutes preoperatively to determine the level of compression to help in endotracheal tube placement. It also helps in some cases to rule out other causes of upper airway obstruction and is part of the work up carried by a pulmonary specialist.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Evaluation -- Bronchoscopy. Bronchoscopy is not useful in the identification of vascular rings. It is done in certain institutes preoperatively to determine the level of compression to help in endotracheal tube placement. It also helps in some cases to rule out other causes of upper airway obstruction and is part of the work up carried by a pulmonary specialist.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Evaluation -- Barium Swallow
content: This is not superior to CTA and MRA, and has no longer used in the evaluation of suspected vascular rings. Posterior indentation of the esophagus indicates a vascular ring. Precise identification of the anatomy of the vascular ring is not possible. Anterior indentation indicates a pulmonary vascular sling.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Evaluation -- Barium Swallow. This is not superior to CTA and MRA, and has no longer used in the evaluation of suspected vascular rings. Posterior indentation of the esophagus indicates a vascular ring. Precise identification of the anatomy of the vascular ring is not possible. Anterior indentation indicates a pulmonary vascular sling.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Treatment / Management
content: Since all symptoms result from mechanical compression, there is no role for medical treatment, and surgical correction is the only definitive treatment available with excellent clinical outcomes. Surgery is indicated only in symptomatic individuals.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Treatment / Management. Since all symptoms result from mechanical compression, there is no role for medical treatment, and surgical correction is the only definitive treatment available with excellent clinical outcomes. Surgery is indicated only in symptomatic individuals.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Treatment / Management -- Right Aortic Arch with Aberrant LSCA
content: Through a posterolateral left thoracotomy, the left-sided PDA or ligamentum or atretic segment is divided, which results in the release of the vascular ring. [5] Diverticulum of Kommerell, if prominent, has also been removed to avoid reoperation for persistent or recurrent esophageal or tracheal compression symptoms. [8]
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Treatment / Management -- Right Aortic Arch with Aberrant LSCA. Through a posterolateral left thoracotomy, the left-sided PDA or ligamentum or atretic segment is divided, which results in the release of the vascular ring. [5] Diverticulum of Kommerell, if prominent, has also been removed to avoid reoperation for persistent or recurrent esophageal or tracheal compression symptoms. [8]

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Treatment / Management -- Double Aortic Arch
content: Using preoperative imaging, the site of the surgical division is selected. This is usually an atretic segment in the smaller of the two arches, which is, in most cases, the left-sided arch. Using a left-sided posterolateral thoracotomy, the ductus or ligamentum must also be divided to release the ring.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Treatment / Management -- Double Aortic Arch. Using preoperative imaging, the site of the surgical division is selected. This is usually an atretic segment in the smaller of the two arches, which is, in most cases, the left-sided arch. Using a left-sided posterolateral thoracotomy, the ductus or ligamentum must also be divided to release the ring.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Treatment / Management -- Pulmonary Artery Sling
content: Cardiopulmonary bypass and midline sternotomy approach are used. Relocation of the left pulmonary artery to anterior of the trachea is done in patients with extrinsic tracheal compression without fixed stenosis. In patients with a complete tracheal ring, tracheal resection of the affected portion is most often needed. [9] [10]
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Treatment / Management -- Pulmonary Artery Sling. Cardiopulmonary bypass and midline sternotomy approach are used. Relocation of the left pulmonary artery to anterior of the trachea is done in patients with extrinsic tracheal compression without fixed stenosis. In patients with a complete tracheal ring, tracheal resection of the affected portion is most often needed. [9] [10]

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Treatment / Management -- Recent Advances
content: Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgical (VATS) [11] and endoscopic robotic-assisted surgical techniques [12] are being used as an alternative to open thoracotomy in advanced treatment centers and show initial promising results with reduced length of stay.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Treatment / Management -- Recent Advances. Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgical (VATS) [11] and endoscopic robotic-assisted surgical techniques [12] are being used as an alternative to open thoracotomy in advanced treatment centers and show initial promising results with reduced length of stay.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Differential Diagnosis -- Otolaryngology
content: Congenital or acquired laryngeal abnormalities
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Differential Diagnosis -- Otolaryngology. Congenital or acquired laryngeal abnormalities

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Differential Diagnosis -- Respiratory
content: Asthma Recurrent pneumonia Tracheoesophageal fistula, tracheomalacia, congenital tracheal anomalies
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Differential Diagnosis -- Respiratory. Asthma Recurrent pneumonia Tracheoesophageal fistula, tracheomalacia, congenital tracheal anomalies

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Differential Diagnosis -- Gastrointestinal
content: Gastroesophageal reflux disease Esophageal motility disorders
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Differential Diagnosis -- Gastrointestinal. Gastroesophageal reflux disease Esophageal motility disorders

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Differential Diagnosis -- Others
content: External compression of the trachea or esophagus by mediastinal mass (e.g., Hodgkin lymphoma)
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Differential Diagnosis -- Others. External compression of the trachea or esophagus by mediastinal mass (e.g., Hodgkin lymphoma)

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Prognosis
content: In children with vascular rings, surgical correction is not associated with any mortality. Rare reported cases of mortality in the vascular ring have been associated with other congenital heart disease or underlying pulmonary pathology. [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [13] More than 70% of patients become asymptomatic after one year after surgical correction. However, respiratory symptoms can persist up to four to six months after surgery. [4] The need for reoperation is very low (8%), and the most common reasons for it include persistence of diverticulum, circumflex aortic arch, scarring, and tracheobronchomalacia needing aortopexy. [14]
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Prognosis. In children with vascular rings, surgical correction is not associated with any mortality. Rare reported cases of mortality in the vascular ring have been associated with other congenital heart disease or underlying pulmonary pathology. [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [13] More than 70% of patients become asymptomatic after one year after surgical correction. However, respiratory symptoms can persist up to four to six months after surgery. [4] The need for reoperation is very low (8%), and the most common reasons for it include persistence of diverticulum, circumflex aortic arch, scarring, and tracheobronchomalacia needing aortopexy. [14]

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Complications
content: Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury and vocal cord paralysis Thoracic duct injury and chylous pleural effusion Vascular complications including narrowing of the vessel, bleeding, and thrombosis Tracheal and esophageal injury
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Complications. Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury and vocal cord paralysis Thoracic duct injury and chylous pleural effusion Vascular complications including narrowing of the vessel, bleeding, and thrombosis Tracheal and esophageal injury

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Deterrence and Patient Education
content: Patients with aortic arch anomalies should be counseled about the risk of the vascular ring and the need for advanced imaging. Once the diagnosis is ruled out, reassurance is necessary. If a vascular ring is identified, necessary steps, including symptoms that need to be watched for, need, and timing of surgery, adequate follow-up needs to be advised to improve symptoms.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Deterrence and Patient Education. Patients with aortic arch anomalies should be counseled about the risk of the vascular ring and the need for advanced imaging. Once the diagnosis is ruled out, reassurance is necessary. If a vascular ring is identified, necessary steps, including symptoms that need to be watched for, need, and timing of surgery, adequate follow-up needs to be advised to improve symptoms.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: Evaluation and management of an individual with a symptomatic vascular ring require the involvement of multiple specialties needing an interprofessional approach.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes. Evaluation and management of an individual with a symptomatic vascular ring require the involvement of multiple specialties needing an interprofessional approach.

title: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: Once the patient is symptomatic, the following specialties are involved: pediatric cardiology, pediatric gastroenterology, pediatric otorhinolaryngology, pediatric pulmonology, and finally, the repair is performed by pediatric cardiovascular surgery. Postoperative care and rehabilitation in pediatric ICU will be needed to recognize possible complications that occur immediately following surgical correction.
contents: Vascular Aortic Arch Ring -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes. Once the patient is symptomatic, the following specialties are involved: pediatric cardiology, pediatric gastroenterology, pediatric otorhinolaryngology, pediatric pulmonology, and finally, the repair is performed by pediatric cardiovascular surgery. Postoperative care and rehabilitation in pediatric ICU will be needed to recognize possible complications that occur immediately following surgical correction.
